>my prey capture experiment typically runs at several
>hundred evaluations per second (with 100 simulations
>per evaluation) and therefore searches can run into
>hundreds of thousands, even millions of generations. My
>own belief is that this large number of generations is
>necessary to trawl a multi-dimensional search space
>effectively.

That's an interesting point of view.  I have been influenced greatly
by the experiments done by Ken and other neuroevolution techniques
such as SANE, all of which seem to be able to converge on their
results, topologically and synaptically complex results, in less than
500 generations.  I cannot recall looking over any paper (and there's
been quite a few) where the intended goal took more than 500
generations to reach.

Of course this is probably just my own ignorance and inexperience
showing itself - as I'm assuming that all experiments can be grouped
together, regardless of whether it is using co-evolution or taking
into account how the scenario is designed, etc...  

My scenario is very limited in its opening permutations, for each
skill, and I cannot simply place characters randomly if I hope to
achieve any sort of meaningful fitness evaluation.  After much thought
I think the scenario design is sound, so perhaps I am just not giving
NEAT enough time to evolve the appropriate solution(s).

After 719 generations on the hardest memory test possible (scenario
E), my recurrent NN has achieved a fitness of 5005 out of 5107, so far
so good.

Mike
